Posts.Content: Harley44 wrote: Hi... It's me again...  I had a Neulasta shot in the LE arm, and a couple of weeks later, my hand swelled up!  It was just AWFUL!  This was back in September...  I went to an LE therapist and she put my arm in a machine, and it 'decompressed' my arm and hand.  It SEEMED to work pretty well the FIRST time she used it, but I had a few more txs, and it never worked as well.  I also got a glove and a sleeve to wear, 'just in case', since my arm never got any swelling.  I wore the glove, but when I would take it off at the end of the day, and I was told NOT to wear it at night, when I'm sleeping, my hand was all puffy.  WTH?  So I stopped wearing the glove, and the swelling seemed to go down to a 'tolerable' lever.  Now understand, it STILL looks BIGGER than the other hand, but it doesn't look all puffy, like the Pillsburgy DoughBoy.  My joints also hurt, when I make a fist.  Now I don't do the exercises like she showed me either, but when I DO them, I don't notice any change.  I am so frustrated about all this, because it would NEVER have happened, if that stupid onc nurse hadn't given me the Neulasta shot.  My LE therapist told me that I should be grateful that my LE was very mild, and my arm didn't swell up like a tree trunk.  Still, I just wish it would go back to the way it was before bc.... Any ideas? Harley Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: LE and Neulasta shot... Harley44 Harley44

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 07:43AM Harley44 wrote: Sharon, After that first Neulasta shot, I had them in my abdomen.  After my 1st chemo, I was not given Neulasta, but my onc waited til my wbc tanked, THEN he gave me Neupogen and I had to give it to myself, and it was just AWFUL!  I had terrible bone pain from those shots!  The Neulasta was MUCH BETTER!  Binney, I guess I didn't explain properly.  My LE therapist is certified, and she has been doing this kind of therapy for years, and keeps taking classes, so she can keep up on stuff.  She is also the only one in the area, and NO ONE takes my insurance, so I am stuck with them.  She also did the massage, and it felt good.  Don't get me wrong.  The actual "swelling" has gone down, but it is just that I now have a MAN hand, it is just BIGGER than my other hand. I will ask my onc nurse when I see her next month, but I am sure that there is nothing they can do.  I am very concerned that whenever I wear the glove, my hand gets puffy.... WTH?  I thought it was supposed to keep things under control...  I stopped wearing it, cause it was NO HELP at all.  My dh got mad at first, but one day I wore the glove ALL DAY, and then showed him what it looked like when I took it off.  and yes, I know, I know, I am supposed to do this massage myself, but as I said, the exercises don't seem to have any effect on this.  Thanks... I'll see what my onc nurse says.  I hate the idea that I'll just have to keep going for more LE therapy, for the rest of my life, and my insurance SUCKS,  I don't know WHY my pcp dr's office is always so NASTY!!   If I can get the necessary referrals from my pcp, the insurance works well, but NO ONE wants to take it, because they don't pay the drs. very much... ......sigh....  and my dh wonders why I am so depressed, and why I get into a screaming match with my dr.?  Thanks Harley

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2007 06:51PM Harley44 wrote: Barb, Wow!  It's good to hear that you are almost finished with your txs!  I'll be thinking about you on Tuesday... I have an appt. with an LE specialist on Monday, at 9AM... about my swollen hand, from mild lymphedema. Yes, I am a little bit afraid... facing another surgery...  but it will be nice to have breasts again.  I think I should get SOMETHING positive out of this, even if it IS BIGGER BREASTS!  I've always been small, so I am going just a little bigger... No, I think just about all the women I read about here have done the reconstruction at the same time as the mast., but I am using the all in one expander/implant, so I won't need that second "exchange" surgery that most women get.  My ps will still do the 'fills' until they are the right size, but I just get to skip that other surgery.  My ps and my general surgeon did not want me to have this surgery BEFORE the chemo, but other drs. would probably have done it... My drs. were just SO AFRAID of infection, with me starting chemo, even though I wasn't sure I was going to get the chemo at first... I read your post about working out, and I went for a walk yesterday, too, because I was just SO tired, and I was worried I wouldn't get out again for awhile, due to the fatigue...  I didn't walk today, but I will try to make an effort tomorrow.  I usually get out for a walk or run every other day or so.  I think it is important in keeping all the nasty se's at bay... Is the Iscador given in the veins, as chemo is?  If so, I would have to say NO...  I have had enough of chemo for now...  lol In an earlier post, you mentioned that I am brave and strong, but really... I'm not... Since all this bc stuff happened, I have been wanting to hide under the bed with my cat, Spike... but he isn't even going under there anymore... But, if a chicken like me can get through these treatments, so can ALL THE REST of you STRONG WOMEN!! Hugs Harley

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2010 08:02PM Harley44 wrote: Hello GRD4711 I have only just started Femara one week ago...  I took Tamoxifen for 2 years, and my onc's plan was to switch me to an AI after 2 years on Tamoxifen.  So... here I am... I worry about the AIs because they cause osteoporosis... and elevated cholesterol levels...  I've read about joint pain.  But for the joint pain, I have been increasing my vitamin D.  It helps with our BONES also... and it seems to be helping me with my depression.  I've been doing the extra vitamin d for about 5 days or so...  I don't like prunes, so I am taking more vitamin D...  I also found that at first I had a bit of dizziness.  Another disturbing se I'm having is that I am finding that I am very HUNGRY and I think it's from the Femara... this didn't happen with Tamoxifen... so that is the lowdown.... so far... but it's only been a week.  Maybe we can support each other, and help out with motivation for exercise, and the like.... Good Luck to us all!!! Harley

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2008 05:35PM - edited Sep 10, 2008 05:40PM by Harley44 It has been almost a year since I finished chemo, and I am still battling fatigue.  I felt the fatigue during my last 2 txs, and I was still very tired for about 3 weeks post chemo.  I did start to feel better for awhile, but in May I started a little p/t job, and  8/13, I had a D & C for uterine polyps, caused by Tamoxifen.  I have been taking Tamoxifen since last Nov.  Anyway, I just saw my pcp dr. and told him that for the past week, especially, I have been feeling so very tired!  He ran some bloodwork, and gave me a B-12 shot.  The jury is still out, but I DO seem to feel a little bit better.  I know someone, a former co-worker, who told me that she used to get B-12 shots, and they worked magic for her!  She said that she would go in to the dr. office feeling very tired, and she was also very moody, and within a half hour, she was feeling so much better!  I am not sure, but maybe due to the Tamoxifen, I am still not sleeping too well, and I wonder if that isn't part of my problem with fatigue.  Anyway, I am going to try to add some more supplements to my vitamin regimen, to see if that helps any.  The only problem with that is I do not always take the vitamins every day... I know, very stupid of me. Hope you all are feeling better soon.  I also exercise when I have time, but with this p/t job, it's hard to try to fit it in.  Edited to add:  Nicki, a thyroid disorder isn't always so easily treated.  I have been taking Levotyroxine for the past 10 years, and I still have problems with fatigue alot...  My drs. think it is just a matter of taking a pill every day, and you are all better, but it isn't.  I think it may be that for me, at least, I have Hashimotos thyroiditis, which is an auto immune disorder, and my body thinks that my thyroid is a foreign invader, so it is always trying to fight it.  That is just my two cents worth... Harley

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2008 12:44PM Harley44 wrote: Hi Lani, I had the same Oncotype score you did...28!  I thought that was HUGE!  I was 43 when dx'd with bc, but it was just a month before my birthday.  My onc didn't care if I got chemo or not... I also spent ALOT of time, mulling the chemo decision over in my mind, and it took longer for me to get the Oncotype test, because my insurance wouldn't pay for it. He was a SECOND opinion onc., because the first guy was just too blase for me... he said "You have to trust me..."  WTH??  HOW can I trust someone I JUST MET, with my LIFE???  The second opinion onc helped me to get the Oncotype test, and the company isn't going to charge me for the test, even though my insurance refused to pay for it.  I found out later, that he wanted me to get AC, and Adriamycin is one of the MOST toxic chemo drugs, and can cause heart problems.  I believe that we have to research this and do what is best for us... I also believe that we only have ONE LIFE, so while we shouldn't think that we have to get chemo, we need to do research, and find the best chemo drugs for us... I ended up getting 4 txs of Taxotere & Cytoxan, and I am here over a year since my bc dx, and I can tell you that it is definitely DOABLE..  No, it's no fun, but I am the biggest chicken, and if I could do it, SO CAN YOU!! As for the 'window of opportunity' for chemo, I started chemo just at the 3 month mark after my bi-lateral mast...  I believe that the chemo worked it's magic, to help prevent recurrence, and I'm now taking Tamoxifen.    My breast surgeon insisted that I get chemo, he felt that because of my age, I had MORE time for a recurrence to occur.  He was the only one who really cared.  My onc and I went toe to toe about which chemo to use, since he found out that my insurance wouldn't pay very much, and he couldn't bill me for the difference.  He wanted to switch me from TC to AC, because Adriamycin is less expensive, and I refused... We get along well now, and my dh said it's because he saw that I wasn't just going to do whatever he said.  Good luck!  I'll be thinking about you and praying for you...  I'm hoping that your new onc will want to start your treatment, ASAP!! Hugs, Harley

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2008 01:46PM - edited Mar 21, 2008 01:47PM by Harley44 Otter, My dh was in the Navy, and he was active duty when I was dx'd and when I got my chemo.  The insurance works the same way yours does... MY onc is not a network provider for TriCare, but once he agreed to see me, he had technically agreed to the contract between Tricare and himself.  He couldn't try to bill me for the difference. I was SO SCARED when I walked into that office on the day of my 1st tx!!  But I didn't let my onc know...  I was glad that my MIL was there, for support, even though there wasn't much she could do.  She saw me go toe to toe with my onc, and she told me that from then on, she wouldn't worry about me, 'cause I can stand up for myself!   Sorry, I digress... After my insurance case manager explained to my onc how the insurance worked, he came in to the room.  I was talking on my cell phone to my case manager when he came in, and I said..."well, I gotta go... I guess my onc is going to tell me that he can't see me anymore..."  The onc said, "Why do you think I'd say that?"  I told him, "because now you know how my insurance works!"  He just laughed.  But, he then told me that he wanted to change out my chemo drugs.  I said... to what?  He said ... "to AC... How do you feel about that?"  I said " I think, If you give me Adriamycin, It will KILL me!"  He backed right up against the wall and said "no chemo for you!"  I was just about to leave and go home, when I stopped to talk to the woman in the office, and he walked by.  She said "Are you going to do the chemo?"  and he said YES!   So, the short answer, made long by my story, was that my onc just gave in to my request.  He went away, and thought about it, so I didn't know until I got in that chemo chair if he agreed to use TC...  I think if you explain to your onc about your fears, they will agree to the chemo that will work for you, without damaging your heart. Good Luck!  Please let me know how it goes, if you decide to get chemo.  You know, I didn't know that I could stand up for myself like that, so I guess that is yet another thing that having bc has taught me... Hugs Harley P S Sorry for the long post, but now that it's over, it is a rather amusing story.

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2008 10:40PM Harley44 wrote: wallycat is right.  80% of these 'thingies' are b-9, so odds are, it is nothing to worry about. That being said, you should not stop until you get answers.  Someone here has said that the only good lump is in a jar...   Also, if you are feeling tired, and losing weight (without trying, usually), it can be a thyroid issue.  Are you sleeping at night?  If you are suffering from Hyperthyroidism, usually you have trouble sleeping, but that is only one of the symptoms.  The thyroid gland controls so many of your body functions, sometimes it is hard to connect all the different symptoms to the thyroid. Please keep pushing til you get some answers, and post here to let us know how you are doing. Thinking of you, and praying that you will get b-9 results. Hugs, Harley

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2008 03:35PM Harley44 wrote: swm63 If you are waiting on Oncotype test results, is it safe for me to assume that you had ER/PR positive, lymph node negative bc?  That test is used mainly for this type of bc.  If that is the case, then you wouldn't need to start chemo BEFORE your surgery. As a general rule, they usually want to start chemo within 3 months of your surgery, for the lumpectomy.  With that being said, I was so conflicted about the chemo issue, and my insurance would not cover the Oncotype test, that I had my bi-lateral mast. on 5/2/2007, and didn't start chemo til 8/7/2007, because I eventually saw a 2nd opinion onc. who called the Genomic Health co. rep and asked if they would help me.  I spoke to the Genomics rep, and they agreed that we qualified for 100% assistance, and they wrote off the cost of the test.  Anyway, just wanted you to know that I got chemo a little bit later than everyone else.  Your dr. will know for sure if there is a timeline that you need to adhere to.  Good Luck! Harley

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2009 05:57PM Harley44 wrote: Otter, I think you said it very well. When I was 1st dx'd, I remember some people at the coffee shop talking, and they were saying to my dh, 'she has to stay positive!'  Well, yes, that is true...  but I don't think anyone can be POSITIVE ALL the time...  I remember thinking "I'm a goner!", so yeah, I had my moments, especially right after I was dx'd.   The worst part for me was all the decisions I had to make.  I took a long time deciding some of my treatment options, and I even got an Oncotype test done, which ended up in that 'gray' area, so no help there...  In the end, I decided to get the most aggressive treatment I could, because as you said, Otter, I felt I was putting on armor to fight this beast...   My family didn't understand why I would get such aggressive treatment, for such a 'small' cancer...   But I did what I thought was best, after much thought.   Oh, and my family stopped calling.  This bothered me. My treatment went well.  Some people, friends and neighbors, would see me walking in the neighborhood, and everyone kept saying how I looked so good, and I seemed to be doing very well.   The day after my bilateral mast., when I got home from the hospital, I went for a walk... drains and all.  And, Otter, I had worried, too about things that never happened...  I worried I'd be very sick from the chemo, I worried that I'd end up in the hospital from the chemo, but I didn't get sick, and I didn't end up in the hospital.  I'll be 3 years out from dx on March 15th 2010.   I feel pretty good; I also have those kind of appts. with my drs.  When I saw my onc a couple of weeks ago, I even hugged him... something I would NEVER have thought would happen.   I don't get scans, and at first, that bothered me.  But I think I would probably feel so anxious, waiting for results.  But, for me, it IS a new normal, because there are always so many things to think about...  reading labels at the store, to be sure nothing has soy in it, thinking about switching from Tamoxifen to an AI... there always seems to be some kind of decision I have to make, because I want to do everything I can to make sure this bc monster doesn't come back.  I don't know if I would have the strength to fight him again!!  Harley

I have seen this in two places, and one is Cure Magazine, it is noted that Effexor is a weak inhibitor of Tamoxifen...    Probably since there aren't very many anti depressants that you can take, it is one that would interfere the least, so it is probably fine for you to take it.   FWIW, my primary care dr.'s wife had bc 25 years ago, when she was 30, and he told me that SHE also took Tamoxifen, and Wellbutrin, which is a POTENT inhibitor of Tamoxifen, and she is fine today...  so who knows?? I just had so much trouble when I stopped Effexor.  I even had a meltdown in the Wal Mart.  So I am a bit skittish about starting up again.  Maybe I'll wait to see how the increased D3 works for me.  Good Luck with Effexor...  I'm sure it'll be fine. Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2007 08:19AM - edited Oct 24, 2007 08:20AM by Harley44 Wintermoon: I don't know your specific info. on your breast cancer, but if the tumor is very small (less than 1 cm), you may not need to get chemo...  it really just depends on what your dr. recommends.  Also, the stage of your bc, and whether or not the lymph nodes were positive... I had a small tumor, .8cm, stage I, grade 2, no lymph node involvement,  HER2 negative, ER+/PR+...   So, my doctors thought I may benefit from chemo also.  I was in the gray area, and the decision was left up to me.  There is a test called the Oncotype DX test, which tests part of the bc tissue they took out.  It assigns a number to the tissue based on all the 'personality traits' of the bc, some of which I  mentioned about mine... size, grade, etc.  and it predicts your risk for recurrence in the next 10 years.  This helps to decide whether chemo may help you.   Usually, if the tumor was ER+, the pills, Tamoxifen or another type estrogen inhibitor are effective in blocking estrogen's effects on any bc  cancer cells that may still be in your system.  Because in my case, the Oncotype test results were RIGHT IN THE MIDDLE, it was not much help for me.  So, I decided to go ahead and get the chemo, too.  This way, I can be sure that I did ALL I CAN to prevent recurrence.  However, you may not need chemo. If you get chemo, you will have chemo BEFORE you get radiation or the hormone treatment.  Depending on which surgery option you choose, you may or may not need radiation.  I had bi-lateral mastectomy (BOTH breasts were removed, to make my reconstruction easier.), and did not need to get radiation.  So, since I finished my chemo on Oct. 9th, and I really had minimal side effects from it, I will need to start the hormone treatment soon.  I may take Tamoxifen for a couple of years, and then switch to one of the other options, like Arimidex or Aromasin, or Femara.  I would take one of these for maybe 5 years...  I hope I didn't give you too much information, but that was just my experience.  It has been a long journey, but once I made the decision to get chemo, it has gone pretty quickly, and I am here to say that even if your drs. recommend chemo, it is definitely DOABLE!  It isn't something that any of us WANT to do, and I wouldn't want to do it again, but WE CAN DO IT!!  I will be having my reconstruction surgery on Nov. 7th, and that is only 2 weeks away!! Good Luck!  Post often, please let me know how you are doing.  I really think that it helps to talk with others who have been through the same experiences.  We understand, and will support you, whatever decisions you make along the way. Hugs, Harley

Welcome!  I am sorry you had to join this club, but I am glad that you found us!  You will find the women & men here are very warm, helpful and supportive... and Knowledgeagble too! I had Stage I bc,  .8 cm, estrogen & progesterone positive.  What this means is that the tumor is very sensitive to these hormones, and they make it grow.  So the pills the dr. told you about would most likely be Tamoxifen, or Arimidex.  You don't say how old you are, but if you are young, and pre-menopausal, you will likely be given Tamoxifen.  I am post-menopausal, age 44, as I have a condition which put me into menopause very early.  For us Post-menopausal women, the Arimidex has been found to be very effective.  My dr. has told me that I will be starting Tamoxifen soon, since I was concerned about some of the side effects of Arimidex.  There is ALOT to learn, and this bc journey can be a rollercoaster ride at times, especially with all the emotional turmoil it causes.  But, it will be just a bump in the road for you.  You WILL get through this!  There are lots of other women here who will give you lots of good advice, too! Good Luck! Post any time you like.  It seems to me that only other women who have been through this bc experience can truly understand what we are going through. Best wishes, Harley

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2007 11:55AM Harley44 wrote: Trish, That is a GREAT story!  Prior to my dx, I worked at a company that manufactured materials from recycled wood pieces... they made pet bedding, and cat litter, and were working on wood pellets for fuel in Wood Pellet Stoves... Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2007 10:43AM Harley44 wrote: somalley I had the Oncotype test, but it was no help for me... it was RIGHT IN THE MIDDLE!, a 28 which I thought was a HUGE chance for recurrence... I'm not sure it is correct...  If I were you, I wouldn't  count on getting an Oncotype score that will help with your decision.  At first I said NO to the chemo, but after much reflection, I decided to go for it, and I'm glad I did.  The factors that made me decide were:  1   I am 44 y.o.  and my surgeon said I should get the chemo, since I am still relatively young.  The younger you are, the more time we have left to live, and the more time we have left to live, the more time the bc has to recur... It comes back in some really terrible places, too... 2  I want to make sure that I have done ALL I CAN to prevent bc recurrence...  I only have ONE life!!  Good Luck with your decision.  I know how hard it is... whatever you decide, keep posting.  We are here for you, and support you! Harley
Posts.Title: Trying to decide about chemo somalley somalley

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2007 05:47PM Harley44 wrote: Lisa, I was also terrified of chemo, and I took longer than anyone to decide.  I had a second opinion onc. who helped me get the Oncotype test, and it was right in the middle... at first, I said NO, to chemo, since my new onc said the benefit was only 4%... but I changed my mind and am now halfway through my chemo tx... I say all this just so you know that even though my surgery was May 2nd and I started chemo on Aug. 7th... so it was just over 3 months from my surgery date, but I feel confident that I am getting rid of any microscopic bc that may be hanging around.  My age was a big factor in deciding about chemo... I am 44, so I am still relatively young, and my drs. said that the younger you are, the longer you still have to live, and the more time for you to have a recurrence, so that put me at higher risk for recurrence than I originally thought I would be, and I just was not comfortable with my decision to pass on chemo... Also, it has gone well, so don't worry... the worst thing is the unknown.  It won't be nearly as bad as you are imagining.  I know you will make the right decision for you. Good Luck with your decision!  HARLEY
